header: The 2015 edition of YAPC::NA is now behind us, and most of its pilgrims have returned from Salt Lake City. If you missed -- or want to know what all the noise is about -- look in the 'video' section for a link to its YouTube channel. Hopefully, it'll give you the itch to come and join us next year. Enjoy! ~ `/anick
subject: Yet Another YAPC Pleasingly Concluded

entries.author: charlie_gonzalez
entries.title: What I learned at Perl MiniConf
entries.text: Fresh from the New York hackaton of last May, Charlie jumped back into the fray and  attended the recent Perl mini-conference that happened in the Big Apple.

entries.author: dave_rolsky
entries.title: Why Use Go?
entries.text: Different tools are good for different tasks. When is it better to use Perl, and when is it better to use Go? Dave gives us his two cents on the topic.

entries.author: david_farrell
entries.title: Get to grips with Prove, Perl's test workhorse
entries.text: Perl's testing ecosystem is awesome. One of its core tools is 'prove'. If  you don't already know how to use it, you're in luck: David will show you the important bits.

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.title: Seamless Mesh of JS Tests With Perl Harness? Yes.
entries.text: Running JavaScript tests from within a Perl TAP testsuite? Don't mind if we do.

entries.author: paul_evans
entries.title: Turning a Hard Problem Into an Easy One
entries.text: Paul is working on adding a 'pairsort' function to List::Util. Something that, at first, looked rather daunting, until he began to look at the problem from a different angle...

entries.title: Mojo::Snoo v0.10 - "Snoo" Explained
entries.author: curtis_brandt
entries.text: Curtis introduces Mojo::Snoo. What's Mojo::Snoo? A Mojo wrapper for the Reddit API. Obviously.

Premature optimization is the root of all evil. But sometimes the need for speed is legitimate. Helmut needed Algorithm::Diff to be fast and put his nose to the grindstone. Fairly impressive sparks ensues.
entries.title: Tuning Algorithm::Diff
entries.author: helmut_wollmersdorfer

entries.text: Camspi dives into the world of Dancer2 request parameters -- where they are coming from, how to to select subsets of them based on their source, that kind of stuff.
entries.title: Dancer2 Named Route Parameters
Perl Koding
entries.text: Jesse draws our attention on Koding.com, which offers a cloud-based IDE for development (supporting, amongst other languages/environment, Perl, natch).

entries.author: andrew_solomon
entries.title: Statefulness and cookies - three ways to implement sessions
entries.text: Cookies. They are delicious. Or, at the very least, darn useful in a web framework context. Andrew shows three different ways they can be used in Dancer2.

entries.title: Make a playlist quickly
entries.author: thomas_klausner
entries.text: domm was in charge of the music for his sister wedding. He also had over twelve thousand songs to sift through. It goes without saying, the scene was laid for a small script to come riding in and save the day (or, at least, shorten its workload by a few hours).
To practice his hand at Perl6, Helmut ported two of his CPAN modules, Net::Similarity and Bag::Similarity to Perl6.
entries.author: helmut_wollmersdorfer
entries.title: Porting some modules to Perl6
YAPC::NA 2015 on YouTube
entries.text: Couldn't come to YAPC? A shame. But at least you can access most (if not all) of its talks via its YouTube channel.

entries.title: CPAN great modules released last week
